history.content: yeah you'll probably be fine, just make sure you don't take the hardest classes at the same time. also take like online summer sessions if you can, that helps a ton

children.subject: It's pretty doable - no knock on econ majors, but most classes I have taken outside of EECS are considerably easier (sample size: upperdivs in math, statistics, econ)

I'd like to second the advice of Anonymous Scale. I'm also a double major in Econ + CS, and I will say that even upper division Econ courses typically are significantly less work than most CS classes, simply because there isn't a project component. That being said, I think the one Econ class that is a comparable amount of work is Econ141 (Econometrics) so just keep that in mind. Also, bear in mind that a lot of the Econ classes will help you knock out some of the breadth requirements anyway (International Studies, Historical Studies, Social Sciences), so even taking 16 units a semester it's fairly straightforward to graduate on time.

Hope this helps!

history.content:
Hello everyone!

I am an intended computer science student, I am also trying to double major in economics. While planning my schedule for the next few semesters, I had difficulties keeping the number of units less than or equal to 16-17.

Today, I looked at the sample plan for the MET program and noticed that you should take like 18-21 units per semester. Although I do not plan to apply to the MET program, I am just curious whether it is manageable to take 18-21 units per semester as follows: 2 tech classes (8 units), 2 econ classes (8 units), and a breadth (3-4 units)?

thanks in advance
history.subject: Units per semester
